title: Kris Abdelmessih - Life Through a Volatility Lens (S7E10)

rawLines.text: okay Chris are you ready absolutely all
right three two one Let's
Jam hello and welcome everyone I'm Cory
hoffstein and this is flirting with
models the podcast that pulls back the
curtain to discover the human factor
behind the quantitative
strategy Cory hoffstein is the
co-founder and chief investment officer
of Newfound research due to Industry
regulations he will not discuss any of
new found research's funs on this
podcast all opinions expressed by
podcast participants are solely their
own opinion and do not reflect the
opinion of Newfound research this
podcast is for informational purposes
only and should not be relied upon as a
basis for investment decisions clients
of Newfound research May maintain
positions and securities discussed in
this podcast for more information visit
think newf found.com
[Music]
my guest in this episode is Chris Abdul
msia co-founder of moon tower AI Chris
began his career at Sig where he worked
as a market maker in several different
option pits before moving to Parallax
where he ran a relative value
commodity's volatility book for The Last
5 Years Chris has been writing on his
blog party at the moon tower which is
one of my favorite reads for all things
probability payoff Space Trading
optionality and seeing the world through
a volatility lens Chris is a passionate
educator so it should come as no
surprise that learning is a key thread
throughout this entire episode episode
Chris discusses how learning is
accelerated in the option pits and how
we can think about replicating that in
electronic space he discusses what he
had to unlearn and relearn in his move
from Market making to relative value
trading and Chris shar's thoughts about
how firm lineage influences how you
learn to trade markets finally we
discuss Chris's newest Venture moon
tower AI which seeks to provide a
volatility lens to opinionated traders
to help them better Express their bets
in option space there is a lot of
experience to unpack in this one I hope
you enjoy my conversation with Chris
abdol
msia Chris welcome to the show Mr Moon
toow meta himself longtime fan of the
blog and the newsletter I think it might
be my most recommended newsletter I was
looking earlier as to how many times
I've recommended articles you've written
it's a lot it's a lot you are constantly
churning out great think pieces on
probability and investing particularly
in the option space so very excited to
have you here with me today thank you
for joining me it is beyond a privilege
to be here I'm such a fan of you the way
you carry yourself your honesty the way
you balance being light-hearted but
serious and your writing was massively
inspirational to my own writing and the
way you think about tra trading and
investing is just rare and very Kindred
you're the smarter version of everything
I want to be and I'm a huge fan of the
podcast it's funny I almost feel like
today it's like hey we're taking a break
from our regular episodes with all these
Geniuses to have to bring out a monkey
on a unicycle but I'm just so stoked to
be here so thank you well I feel like
I'm gonna have to edit most of that out
but I appreciate the kind words and I
think at the end of this episode nobody
will be thinking of you as a monkey on a
unicycle and certainly nobody who's read
your writing would think of you that way
but for those who haven't read your
writing for those who maybe aren't as
active on fin twit don't know who you
are can you start us off with a
background because you have had a bit of
a trajectory to your career you've
stayed within the VA space but had a
couple different cuts of how you've
thought about V so maybe we can start at
the beginning your time on the floor and
take us forward to where you are today
yeah so I'll give a brief career bio I
was kind of a traditional entry into the
business I'm also a Cornell Alum I had
an idea that I wanted to go into finance
and trading specifically but I was
walking around a career fair and there
was a booth with a guy that had some
dice and a deck of cards and there was
nobody at the booth because everybody in
their ill-fitting suits was all
surrounding the bankers everybody wanted
to be I don't know Frank quatron or
whatever it's
1999 and this guy just kind of looked at
me wandering around like a lost Fawn
said hey do you like games and there was
nobody else at the booth and nobody knew
who Sig was so I went over there did a
little interview didn't do so great and
I asked him I said I don't feel like I
did very good in this interview but I
like these questions that you asked me
and I like this stuff what can I do to
get better at this and he recommended a
book to me called getting the best of it
by David
sklansky and of course I went and got it
and read it
and I to my surprise got a call back for
a second interview and all the questions
were straight out of the beginning of
that book so I guess he liked me because
he wanted me to get through so I end up
at Sig got into their trainer program I
started on the AMX I spent six to nine
months clerking for various pits
clerking in uh spiders ETFs ETFs were a
relatively new product at the time the
king of ETFs Reggie Brown was my boss
and so I was his clerk that's where I
learned Excel I mean I didn't even know
Excel so I was clerking in spiders and
then I did index options Equity options
all that I was clerking all that went
through their training program lived in
Bak kinwood Pennsylvania for three
months mock trading Theory all the stuff
honestly a lot of the stuff that I write
about was super inspired by what we
learned all those Basics and then after
that was a market maker on the MX floor
in equity options for a couple years
then I was on a New York Stock Exchange
I was a broker for a year and then I was
a specialist in
ETFs for almost a year and then after
that I was asked to go start the oil
options trading business on the NX for
Sig and if I remember correctly they had
failed twice before so it was the
proposition was like hey go over there
see if we can figure it out try not to
lose too much money so it's a great
setup up for I was like high upside low
downside situation so went over there
took us about six months to figure it
out this time we ended up being very
successful and there's a luck component
to it we were going there right at the
transition of the markets going from you
know when I stepped into the pit we was
as we say trading on fingers flashing
our Hedges to the Futures pit markets
were not very electronic at the time
there was a thing called I think it was
called access or something there was
like electron markets at night but it
was open outcry hand signals and all
that but we were coming from a world
where we were used to trading
electronically so basically we were
early adopters of using technology over
there and built that business that went
well traded and then after three years
of doing that I left and I went over to
trading I got backed by a backer in
Chicago so basically like put up some of
my own money and then for almost four
years built my own little market making
operation and I'll talk more about that
later but that we did spent four years
learning to trade a lot of different
commodity products Futures options and
then I went to after that Parallax which
is a big hedge fund in San Francisco
their traditional business is relative
value Equity VA trading also has a bit
of a Sig lineage and they asked me if
I'd move out to California and build a
commodity options trading business for
them so went out there I spent almost a
decade with Parallax and then in 2021
decided to leave The Daily Grind and
since then I started writing about five
years ago so I was at Parallax when I
had started writing online and then by
2021 decided that I didn't want to sit
in front of a screen all day anymore so
I left now I write I teach and my newest
project is an options trading software
that we launched a couple months ago I
think it's clear to anyone who has read
your writing that you think a lot about
thinking and you think a lot about
learning and one of the things you
mentioned to me in our preall is that
you thought the trading floor provided
an environment where your learning rate
can really be accelerated you're
learning right about the market you're
learning right about trading and
something that potentially has been lost
as we move into a more pure electronic
world ious why you think that that
learning rate was so accelerated in the
floor and what exactly is getting lost
as we all go electronic this is a fun
topic for me because I was very fond of
the floor because it was very well
suited to how I learn which is the key
thing on the floor that feels very
different than today is the who because
when you are on the floor you are mixed
in there with all these comp leting
firms as well as all the people from
your own firm and there's a sort of
freny dynamic where you show up to work
every day and you can see what your
competitors are doing but they
competitors right now but tomorrow they
might be employees or you might be
asking them for a job so it is a very
Cooperative but combative ecosystem at
the same time time it's very unique in
that way imagine everybody's sitting
upstairs today on their screens trading
imagine if you just all got in a room
and we trading what that Dynamic could
feel like so on the floor your learning
rate would be very high because you had
this amazing and unique opportunity to
try to reverse engineer what people were
doing so for example a broker might come
to the pit let's say an option is worth
$5 and a broker comes into the pit and
says hey I'll sell1 these at 4.95
everybody in the Pit's going to go buy
them buy them buy them so that's not
interesting but what happens if that
broker comes in the pit and says I'll
sell these at $5 dollar and one market
maker lifts it and then that market
maker says I'll buy more there so what
you have is this new piece of
information why is this one market maker
want to buy these options but the thing
is you've seen this Market maker you
know what firm he works for he's got a
headset on most of the people in the pit
maybe they don't have a headset but this
guy's a headset on so in other words
like he's seeing something that you're
not so what'll happen is maybe three
minutes later all of a sudden you see
that there's all these bids so what
happen is that market maker had an
upstairs Trader that saw something trade
away that knows that Fall's higher but
not everybody else got to see that so
what you're doing is you're waiting The
credibility of the actors like
subconsciously as they make decisions
and from there that is guiding your own
decision process so there's other
examples of this like you might see
you're watching how people lean markets
so you might think that option's worth
$5 dollar but a big Market maker who's
fast is the first person to yell out
that order gets quoted and that market
maker goes
$495 that market maker is heavily
betting that that order is a seller so
by watching smart market makers or
market makers that work for firms that
you know see a lot you can figure out oh
they must have a good feeling for who
this other side is they're tracking
what's going on and you learn to do that
as well so another example is you're
walking by a pit that seems to do no
volume you look it up there doesn't seem
to be a whole lot of options volume in
that pit it's a tumble weed but there's
a smart Trader standing in that pit so
you're like there must be money over
there because why would that firm put a
strong Trader in that pit if it really
was a wasteland so you can kind of
figure out what tables you want to play
at just from walking around the floor
and paying attention so there's a large
poker aspect to it and also just the way
information flows when you're down there
something could be ripping much higher
and is it a short squeeze is it not well
you can talk to Brokers you talk to
other Traders and again you're waiting
everybody's input by how credible you
think they are and that credibility
score that informal creditability score
you have is built up over watching
repeated interactions with these people
all the time so super unique environment
for learning very quickly as someone who
is super passionate about learning and
teaching how do you think that learning
rate can be reclaimed in an electronic
era so first of all I want to back up
for a second and just say that I'm
saying that something is lost but that's
because of my own skill set where I'm a
flesh and blood humanoid I want to see
people's eyes I want to hear how they
bid and how they offer and so for me
something feels like it's lost that
might not be true for everybody when I
think about it electronic markets offer
people ways to disguise their order you
can slice it up what's happening is you
are getting a lot of
information from lots of very very small
transactions and it's big data so it's
almost like the skill set has converged
with sort of like big Tech doing ad
targeting like it's the same kind of
skill set was not the world I grew up in
in trading so I think that there are
people that can have a very high
learning rate if they are attuned to
those methods today but as far as
reclaiming the learning rate I think can
do that by cultivating like Twitter is
amazing you can go online and if you
have good taste and develop taste into
who's a real G versus who's a larper you
can figure out who you can learn from
and even though you're not on the floor
and you have all these opportunities for
serendipitous meetings with other people
because they just happen to be right
next to you you have to put more effort
into it and I think Traders can re claim
some of that learning rate by putting
themselves out there more I think it's a
good idea to sort of like live outwardly
as a Trader more so than the typical
Trader believes there's a bit of a lone
wolf
introversion that does attract people to
trading and I was like that too to some
degree and over time have sort of like
opened up more and I found that Traders
as they've gotten older have told me the
same thing that by opening up more it'
help them to adapt and learn quicker so
I think that that's the way you reclaim
it is just sort of being a little bit
more outward and it's just always this
game of like you got to give to get but
obviously nobody wants to give
information that's super valuable to
what they're doing so there's a bit of a
game there and you got to play that game
but I think that's the way you reclaim
that learning rate after Sig you moved
to Parallax as you mentioned where you
went from being a market maker to
running this relative value book in the
commodity space can you talk a little
bit about the similarities and the
differences between Market making and
running a relative value book what
skills translate what don't and maybe
what was sort of the steepest part of
the uptake curve for you yeah absolutely
let's start with the differences first
so the first thing is your definition of
what's a good trade evolves so I
remember in training distinctly one of
the teachers at Sig had very very
succinctly defined a good trade as if
you buy something and it's bid there
after you bought it that's a good trade
and what's native to that statement is
that you have a free roll I bought
something if I don't like it I get a
free look if I don't like it I can
scratch it by turning around selling it
to the person next to me now that is
true if you're fast so you have to know
where you are in the pecking order you
have to be fast and you also have to be
aware of am I in a situation where I'm
going to know that this trade is going
to go south before other people do so if
everybody finds out at the same time
well you're probably out of luck so
you're more of a flipper in this case so
that's what happens as a market maker
but when you are not a market maker you
don't have that speed Advantage you
don't have time place Advantage like you
did on the floor so you're going to be
holding things more for Value so instead
of buying something for 20 because you
think you're going to flip it for 20 and
a half V in an hour you're buying
something for 20 Vol because you think
that if you hold this over time it's
going to be 24 ball so that's the first
big difference and that's a lower Sharps
thing to do which brings me to the
second big difference which is that
you're sliding across the scale versus
Edge Continuum so when you're a relative
value Trader you're no longer just doing
Arbitrage trades you have to do scalable
trades trades that you believe there's a
risk premium to you're thinking about
what the reason for that is and you are
warehousing risk in my transition that
was the harder part for me because I'm
more of a grinder my bias is more of an
under betting bias than anything so I'm
steady hands you're not going to find me
in the newspaper having blown up but the
cost of that is that you might be under
betting and that was hard for me because
when you move upstairs to more of a
relative value Trader you always
paranoid that I'm missing something what
is a Trader ultimately is somebody that
manages liquidity that is the Core
Essence of the job so if I put this
position on how much can I have on
without affecting the price too much how
much can I have on while still being
able to exit it at some point so all of
those
considerations end up halting basically
like how big you're will to trade so
that was the harder part for me I had
some experience already being with this
warehousing mindset because there's a
couple reasons just a lot of the people
that I met on the floor were less Market
maker types and they were people that
were oriented towards I'm doing this
because this is a value trade like if I
hold this exposure I'm gonna win to this
over time or even early on even like my
first or second year trading ever I
remember I was trading Quest
communication
and this was you like back in the early
2000s I was trading AIG Quest there was
like these accounting scandals and there
was all this like interest people were
buying these CDs on these names and the
CDs sort of the cap structure art people
would go out there and they might sell
the CDs and then they would buy these
really way out of the money teeny puts
and I was trading Quest when Quest kind
of got into that mix and the trade I had
put on there was I had basically sold a
bunch of these way out of the money puts
that were just super fat it was like a
two and a half put trading for like a
buck and a quarter and that there just a
ridiculous price and you would just lean
super short into it like over hedge the
Delta and Quest would just grind down
and that was a trade that made a bunch
of money I watched a colleague do the
same trade in Xerox for 10x the amount
of money like a year or two later you're
warehousing that trade you're just
putting that thing on and saying like
I'm G to kind of trade around this but
really I'm going to hold this sucker so
it wasn't completely foreign to me but
it was still hard to bet the right
amount for the amount of money that we
really needed to make to move the needle
so I got better at that over time but
that transition took a couple years and
similarities about what you can use from
that experience it's really just the
idea of knowing how to the trans action
game is played knowing how a market
maker thinks knowing how are they going
to set the screens up based upon the
flow it's like I know what my adversar
is thinking I know why the screens are
framed a certain way so it's like all
the Cloak and Dagger stuff of like how
do I want to try to get into this trade
is part of your DNA which I think if you
started on the buy side that's probably
less native to you because you're not
setting the table for the people that
are conect come trade with you all the
time you're a taker so in that regard
like let's say in that example I think
vs should be 24 it's trading for 20 I
come in today I look at all the markets
and I see that that VA that I think is
cheap is underperforming today like lots
of things are down this things are down
even more so this is a great day for me
to get in there so I'm working screens
I'm running Algos to be out there buying
and then I'm scouring the broker markets
and saying like which broker is knocking
this thing down let me try to go talk to
them and make sure I'm best bid you know
I want to be mid-market bid for size
here and so maybe that day I buy 50,000
Vega in that name and then tomorrow
maybe that name is outperforming the vs
and all the other names so maybe that vs
up to 22 I still think it's cheap I
think that fall is 24 but I say today
I'm G to sell 15,000 Vega out at these
levels I'm trying to trade around the
position and then what's happening is
over time you are trading for Value but
you are trading around around it in a
way where you're sort of like lowering
your average price because you're
booking trading profits in the meantime
and so I think that that mentality of
hey there's a price at which I will let
some of this go even if I think it's
cheap comes from just being a high
volume Trader so I think that that part
really translates pretty well it
improves your execution he mentioned to
me that early in your transition into
Parallax you had a mentor who said to
you quot do you want to optimize your
p&l on a daily basis or something else
and that this question really unlocked
something for you and I wanted to get
from you directly what did this question
mean to you and how did It ultimately
impact your behavior in your new seat
this was sort of a profound one for me
it was something I needed to hear so the
context here was this is my probably I'm
in first or second year of Parallax and
the context here was that I was trying
to dial in my spot ball correlation
parameter in oil and without getting too
far into the weeds in that your spotv
correlation parameter will have a large
impact on your model Deltas so for
example if you run a spot ball
correlation parameter of say 1% or 100
or negative 100 what you're saying is
every time spot goes up 1% I think fall
comes in 1% which is what I would say is
that's a constant straddle regime that's
saying every time okay so I believe that
the straddle is always around the same
price or sort of like net of theta so
stocks up balls down 1% constant
straddle now obviously that's a slope
and that's a very local slope if the
stock doubles I don't think V haves so
it's clear that that's not a constant
parameter but I was being very locally
minded and the reason was
I was very concerned with my daily
p&l which was a bad habit I sort of
picked up from spending those couple
years as a market maker so you really
don't want to be too dogmatic about your
spotv correlation because it does change
and so what the mentor was doing is he
was encouraging me to zoom out and think
about the expected value of the spotv
correlation rather than overweighting it
to like the recent observations so this
lesson it wasn't new to me I just needed
the reminder because of those years that
I had spent as a grinder so I wrote this
post it's kind of this big post called
if you make money every day you're not
maximizing and that is a line or an idea
that I picked up at Sig the context of
the expression is that hedging and
reducing risk is a cost so really your
goal should be to run the highest
tolerable risk for a given amount of
edge or opportunity you don't want to
hedge more than you need to and what is
how much you need to that is a we'll
call that a black box for now I mean
that is a function of your bank roll
your mandate your emotional balance when
you're running bad your alignment or
incentives with your compensation scheme
and and so forth but you don't want to
hedge more than you need to and you
would see this all the time by the way
like on the floor with the locals that
were not super well capitalized it's
like an options worth the dollar they
buy it for 90 cents and then they're
selling it for 95 cents a minute later
and this is like firable offense if
you're a Sig Trader like you don't do
that you are there to tolerate variance
and to try to get paid as much as you
can so my mentor was just helping me
undo the like brain damage I had picked
up and no offense to those locals they
were under capitalized and that was
probably the right thing for them to do
but I was no longer in that situation
and I needed to be taking a lot of risk
I know you often downplay your knowledge
of mathematics but I would argue a lot
of what you do is quantitative but not
necessarily systematic and in the past
you've said you believe what separates
discretionary from systematic is that
and this is a quote from you
discretionary trading is not ignoring
data just because it's unstructured I
want to turn over to you what did you
mean by that and can you give us some
ideas of the unstructured data that
would influence your view of value so
first of all in areas where data is
highly structured it's going to be very
competitive so so you need to have a lot
of self-awareness of like again like
where are you in the pecking order
always of the way this game is being
played so I think that things are most
interesting when they don't have a lot
of large data precedence and that's
where discretionary trading will sort of
shine and another way to phrase it is
that everybody's in a loow info
state so how are you relatively in a lwi
info state
and this was sort of where I think we
felt strong like for me I would rather
we do these mock trading games like
let's throw everybody in a room and
we'll just have no precedent at all and
just see who walks out of the room with
the most money it's almost like the way
our training sort of was so we like that
environment and in an environment where
you can sort of like data hack things to
death that's not my strong suit so that
is not an area where I necessarily want
to be big so I'll give an example like I
said like I think that these cases where
the data is sparse are where things get
really interesting granted that's not
necessarily that scalable that's sort of
the other problem with it but I want to
go back I like this story is very
instructive of what I'm talking about if
you go back to Spring of 2020 when oil
went below zero so I was trading oil
options I was also a large Trader in Uso
at the time and we basically thought
that Uso Vall was a sale I mean the VA
was very high but I didn't think it was
a sale because it was optically high as
a matter of fact I actually bought a
bunch of Futures options VA at multiples
of the highest V I had ever paid in the
past so it wasn't that I'm like oh
numberers high sell it as a matter of
fact I was buying it in Futures options
it was a sale in Uso and I it was a sale
because it was wrong so why was it wrong
there were three reasons why it was
wrong mostly stemming from the fact that
you Uso was no longer a barrel of oil it
was an option on a barrel of oil so
imagine your short oil Futures and your
long Uso on the upside above zero your
p&l is offset but below zero you can't
lose anymore on your Uso leg and you're
just short oil future so that's a
perfect put hockey stick diagram so Uso
had turned into a put option now the
clue to this
was that it started trading at a premium
to its Nav Now if you're naive you look
at that and you say oh there's a bunch
of retail donkeys that are trying to buy
the bounceback in oil because the price
went down a lot and they're buying the
ETF but if you think harder about it you
realize that Uso is an option and that
premium to nav is actually extrinsic so
that extrinsic can actually be converted
it's a bit messy and we were in
imprecise about it but it can actually
be converted to an implied VA we had an
opinion of exactly how much that premium
should be based upon where the Futures
options Vols were trading at the time so
what we did was well let's go back to
why usool was a sale I just want to
clarify this is because of the corporate
structure around the ETF that it is
limited liability to the investors
correct that they cannot lose more than
they invest versus with the Futures
Contract you could absolutely nobody's
gonna call up Grandma and say you owe us
money because Uso went below zero right
so here was our thinking as why it was a
sale so on the off chance it is a
material but low chance that Uso could
go to zero in the event that it goes to
zero all this extrem time premium and
these long-dated options is going to
zero zero is absorbing barriers it's
like a cash Takeover in a stock so
number one it's like there should be
some discount to these options on the
event that Uso does go to zero so that's
01 that's like this probably the least
of the considerations but it's not a
zero so that's one reason the second
reason is that if you buy Uso you're
getting oil Futures but you're also
getting that embedded put now what's
more volatile a portfolio of oil with a
put or oil so that portfolio that is USO
is fundamentally less volatile and the
way it manifests if you're just looking
at it on a daily basis is that when you
are near zero its premium to nav will be
sort of maximized and as oil rallies off
of zero and it goes up the premium to
the nav is going to decline which means
that the ETF price is not going to go up
as fast likewise on the
downside as oil approaches zero the nav
expands so as the oil future goes down
Uso does not go down as fast and that's
how you will actually see it manifest on
a daily basis so this portfolio that is
called Uso or that's the thing like Uso
is a portfolio and that portfolio is
less volatile than an oil future so
that's the second reason why we
understood that fall should be lower in
Uso relative to the Futures options the
third reason and this is like a bit of a
poker reason so if you remember fund
managers they're facing existential risk
they're worried like our asset could go
to zero our whole business could go to
zero on this product so what did they do
they roll to the next month now they
roll Futures to the next month like the
first thing about understanding what
Futures is that deferred commodity
Futures are less volatile than the
prompt future they have a lower beta
than one to The Prompt future and then
